awd_abstract_narration:
The theory of Quantum Mechanics tells us how electrons, atoms, and all particles that make up matter, behave at a microscopic scale. The theory of Classical Mechanics tells us how bridges, cars, and all parts that make up the objects in our everyday world, behave at a macroscopic scale. Unifying the two in a smooth way, to arrive at a consistent theory of both the microscopic and macroscopic scales is an unsolved problem (the "Quantum Measurement Problem") that has perplexed scientists for about one century. To solve this problem, objects at an intermediate scale, in between the microscopic and macroscopic, need to be studied. This is what the project: "Coherent Electron Control" is aiming to do. Electrons are placed close to a controllable amount of material in a wall, so that the description of how the two interact is neither easily described by Quantum Mechanics, nor Classical Mechanics. The best provisional description available, which is called decoherence theory, can be tested to its limits in this way. On the practical side, the interaction between electrons and walls has stopped the development of sensitive devices based on electrons, called electron interferometers. The walls destroy the useful quantum mechanical properties of the electrons. If this "decoherence" can be overcome, electron devices can be constructed that measure small changes in magnetic fields, and may thus assist, for example, in the detection of submerged submarines that distort the Earth's magnetic field. 

Nanofabricated gratings are used as devices that split electron beams into two parts. These two parts are recombined and show quantum mechanical interference. Walls of doped silicon, gold, and other materials such as graphene and superconductive materials will be placed close to the electron beams used to decohere the electron beams, which causes the quantum mechanical interference to disappear. Four different existing microscopic theories can be tested by the experimental data that will be collected; decoherence theory is an integral part of all four.  The knowledge gained will be used to control and reduce the decoherence and be applied to enlarge the size of existing electron interferometers. In this way it will be attempted to construct the largest and most sensitive electron interferometer in the world. This research project provides experience to graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students in the new research area of free electron quantum optics.

por.por_cntn:
We studied experimentally how an electron quantum mechanical wave is affected by the presence of a nearby wall. The study of controlled wall-decoherence is relevant in the context of the (in)famous Quantum Measurement Problem. Decoherence is also the recognized barrier that limits the scaling up of quantum networks and quantum computers to useful scales. Studying decoherence by experiment, in the context of our fundamental understanding, and for a specific system where theoretical predictions are available, can help us overcome decoherence. In our experiments we create quantum coherent electron beams with nanofabricated technology and pass these electron beams to within one millionth of a meter distance above a surface. We observe that coherence is lost and have in this way created a testbed for the theory. As a result we have ruled out several theoretical models (2018 New J. Phys.20 113030).

We studied experimentally and theoretically in collaboration with the University of Antwerp, Belgium, the Aharonov-Bohm effect. This quantum effect is very rare in that something happens without any classical force. Nevertheless, even though textbooks state there is no force whatsoever at work, it was claimed in the scientific literature that a ?quantum force? was present. We observed this force for the first time (2019, Nature Communications 10, 1700), and derived a general theorem to describe the effect, which leads to a deeper understanding of Quantum Mechanics, see also https://phys.org/news/2019-05-non-newtonian-affecting-particles-flight.html.

We studied an analogue of the quantum double-slit experiment (2016 J. Phys.: Conf. Ser.701 012007) as part of our outreach efforts, see https://www.quantamagazine.org/famous-experiment-dooms-pilot-wave-alternative-to-quantum-weirdness-20181011/.

Overall, our work is of a fundamental nature and provides new understanding in the area of quantum physics.

Pushing the experimental limits has also led to new technological developments. We have recently demonstrated the first electron-optical device made by 3D-printing conducting plastic (patent 16/290194). It is our hope that this technology can lower the cost of electron microscope production and just as optical microscopes have become available in classrooms, so we hope that electron microscopes could become available in college class rooms. This work is driven by the needs of our scientific exploration, and may lead to new products, strengthening our national industry. Our work led to three graduate students obtaining the Ph.D. who found immediate employment.  Undergraduate students and high school students were engaged in successful training in this area of National Need. Through the funding of this continuing grant and our outreach efforts in collaboration with the Perimeters institute our study materials have reached over 100,000 high school students for our work on double slit electron diffraction.
